H0.text: Famous scientists have the best ideas, illustrating how the quote applies to scientific knowledge by emphasizing that credit is given to those who convince the world, not necessarily to those who first conceive an idea.

H1.text: Ideas must be communicated to the public because, as Sir William Osler said, credit in science goes to the person who convinces the world rather than the original idea‑generator, underscoring the importance of sharing scientific knowledge with society.

H2.text: In order to be important, ideas must be believable, as Sir William Osler’s statement that credit in science goes to the person who convinces the world rather than the one who first had the idea illustrates for scientific knowledge.

H3.text: The results are less important than the ideas in an experiment, reflecting Sir William Osler’s view that in science credit goes to the person who convinces the world rather than the one who first conceives the idea.
